segment.source: Upgrade to Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (Windows 10)
segment.target: Upgrade to Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (Windows 10)

segment.source: The simplest path to upgrade PCs that are currently running Windows 7, Windows 8, or Windows 8.1 to Windows 10 is through an in-place upgrade.
segment.target: The simplest path to upgrade PCs that are currently running Windows 7, Windows 8, or Windows 8.1 to Windows 10 is through an in-place upgrade.

segment.source: Upgrade to Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit
segment.target: Upgrade to Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: The simplest path to upgrade PCs that are currently running Windows 7, Windows 8, or Windows 8.1 to Windows 10 is through an in-place upgrade.
segment.target: The simplest path to upgrade PCs that are currently running Windows 7, Windows 8, or Windows 8.1 to Windows 10 is through an in-place upgrade.

segment.source: You can use a Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2 task sequence to completely automate the process.
segment.target: You can use a Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2 task sequence to completely automate the process.

segment.source: Proof-of-concept environment
segment.target: Proof-of-concept environment

segment.source: For the purposes of this topic, we will use four machines: DC01, MDT01, and PC0001.
segment.target: For the purposes of this topic, we will use four machines: DC01, MDT01, and PC0001.

segment.source: DC01 is a domain controller and MDT01 is a Windows Server 2012 R2 standard machine, fully patched with the latest security updates, and configured as a member server in the fictional contoso.com domain.
segment.target: DC01 is a domain controller and MDT01 is a Windows Server 2012 R2 standard machine, fully patched with the latest security updates, and configured as a member server in the fictional contoso.com domain.

segment.source: PC0001 is a machine with Windows 7 SP1, targeted for the Windows 10 upgrade.
segment.target: PC0001 is a machine with Windows 7 SP1, targeted for the Windows 10 upgrade.

segment.source: For more details on the setup for this topic, please see Deploy Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.
segment.target: For more details on the setup for this topic, please see Deploy Windows 10 with the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit.

segment.source: fig 1
segment.target: fig 1

segment.source: Figure 1.
segment.target: Figure 1.

segment.source: The machines used in this topic.
segment.target: The machines used in this topic.

segment.source: Set up the upgrade task sequence
segment.target: Set up the upgrade task sequence

segment.source: MDT 2013 Update 2 adds support for Windows 10 deployment, including a new in-place upgrade task sequence template that makes the process really simple.
segment.target: MDT 2013 Update 2 adds support for Windows 10 deployment, including a new in-place upgrade task sequence template that makes the process really simple.

segment.source: Create the MDT production deployment share
segment.target: Create the MDT production deployment share

segment.source: The steps to create the deployment share for production are the same as when you created the deployment share to create the custom reference image:
segment.target: The steps to create the deployment share for production are the same as when you created the deployment share to create the custom reference image:

segment.source: On MDT01, log on as Administrator in the CONTOSO domain with a password of P@ssw0rd.
segment.target: On MDT01, log on as Administrator in the CONTOSO domain with a password of P@ssw0rd.

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, right-click Deployment Shares and select New Deployment Share.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, right-click Deployment Shares and select New Deployment Share.

segment.source: On the Path page, in the Deployment share path text box, type E:MDTProduction, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Path page, in the Deployment share path text box, type E:MDTProduction, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Share page, in the Share name text box, type MDTProduction$, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Share page, in the Share name text box, type MDTProduction$, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Descriptive Name page, in the Deployment share description text box, type MDT Production, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Descriptive Name page, in the Deployment share description text box, type MDT Production, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Options page, accept the default settings and click Next twice, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Options page, accept the default settings and click Next twice, and then click Finish.

segment.source: Using File Explorer, verify that you can access the MDT01MDTProduction$ share.
segment.target: Using File Explorer, verify that you can access the MDT01MDTProduction$ share.

segment.source: Add Windows 10 Enterprise x64 (full source)
segment.target: Add Windows 10 Enterprise x64 (full source)

segment.source: In these steps we assume that you have copied the content of a Windows 10 Enterprise x64 ISO to the E:DownloadsWindows 10 Enterprise x64 folder.
segment.target: In these steps we assume that you have copied the content of a Windows 10 Enterprise x64 ISO to the E:DownloadsWindows 10 Enterprise x64 folder.

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, expand the Deployment Shares node, and then expand MDT Production.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, expand the Deployment Shares node, and then expand MDT Production.

segment.source: Right-click the Operating Systems node, and create a new folder named Windows 10.
segment.target: Right-click the Operating Systems node, and create a new folder named Windows 10.

segment.source: Expand the Operating Systems node, right-click the Windows 10 folder, and select Import Operating System.
segment.target: Expand the Operating Systems node, right-click the Windows 10 folder, and select Import Operating System.

segment.source: Use the following settings for the Import Operating System Wizard:
segment.target: Use the following settings for the Import Operating System Wizard:

segment.source: Full set of source files
segment.target: Full set of source files

segment.source: Source directory: E:DownloadsWindows 10 Enterprise x64
segment.target: Source directory: E:DownloadsWindows 10 Enterprise x64

segment.source: Destination directory name: W10EX64RTM
segment.target: Destination directory name: W10EX64RTM

segment.source: After you add the operating system, in the Operating Systems / Windows 10 folder, double-click the added operating system name in the Operating System node and change the name to the following: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Default Image
segment.target: After you add the operating system, in the Operating Systems / Windows 10 folder, double-click the added operating system name in the Operating System node and change the name to the following: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Default Image

segment.source: figure 2
segment.target: figure 2

segment.source: Figure 2.
segment.target: Figure 2.

segment.source: The imported Windows 10 operating system after you rename it.
segment.target: The imported Windows 10 operating system after you rename it.

segment.source: Create a task sequence to upgrade to Windows 10 Enterprise
segment.target: Create a task sequence to upgrade to Windows 10 Enterprise

segment.source: Using the Deployment Workbench, select Task Sequences in the MDT Production node, and create a folder named Windows 10.
segment.target: Using the Deployment Workbench, select Task Sequences in the MDT Production node, and create a folder named Windows 10.

segment.source: Right-click the new Windows 10 folder and select New Task Sequence.
segment.target: Right-click the new Windows 10 folder and select New Task Sequence.

segment.source: Use the following settings for the New Task Sequence Wizard:
segment.target: Use the following settings for the New Task Sequence Wizard:

segment.source: Task sequence ID: W10-X64-UPG
segment.target: Task sequence ID: W10-X64-UPG

segment.source: Task sequence name: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Upgrade
segment.target: Task sequence name: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Upgrade

segment.source: Template: Standard Client Upgrade Task Sequence
segment.target: Template: Standard Client Upgrade Task Sequence

segment.source: Select OS: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM RTM Default Image
segment.target: Select OS: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM RTM Default Image

segment.source: Specify Product Key: Do not specify a product key at this time
segment.target: Specify Product Key: Do not specify a product key at this time

segment.source: Full Name: Contoso
segment.target: Full Name: Contoso

segment.source: Organization: Contoso
segment.target: Organization: Contoso

segment.source: Internet Explorer home page: about:blank
segment.target: Internet Explorer home page: about:blank

segment.source: Admin Password: Do not specify an Administrator Password at this time
segment.target: Admin Password: Do not specify an Administrator Password at this time

segment.source: figure 3
segment.target: figure 3

segment.source: Figure 3.
segment.target: Figure 3.

segment.source: The task sequence to upgrade to Windows 10.
segment.target: The task sequence to upgrade to Windows 10.

segment.source: Perform the Windows 10 upgrade
segment.target: Perform the Windows 10 upgrade

segment.source: To initiate the in-place upgrade, perform the following steps on PC0003 (currently running Windows 7 SP1).
segment.target: To initiate the in-place upgrade, perform the following steps on PC0003 (currently running Windows 7 SP1).

segment.source: Start the MDT deployment wizard by running the following command: MDT01MDTProduction$ScriptsLiteTouch.vbs
segment.target: Start the MDT deployment wizard by running the following command: MDT01MDTProduction$ScriptsLiteTouch.vbs

segment.source: Select the Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Upgrade task sequence, and then click Next.
segment.target: Select the Windows 10 Enterprise x64 RTM Upgrade task sequence, and then click Next.

segment.source: figure 4
segment.target: figure 4

segment.source: Figure 4.
segment.target: Figure 4.

segment.source: Upgrade task sequence.
segment.target: Upgrade task sequence.

segment.source: On the Credentials tab, specify the MDTBA account, P@ssw0rd password, and CONTOSO for the domain.
segment.target: On the Credentials tab, specify the MDTBA account, P@ssw0rd password, and CONTOSO for the domain.

segment.source: (Some or all of these values can be specified in Bootstrap.ini so they are automatically populated.)
segment.target: (Some or all of these values can be specified in Bootstrap.ini so they are automatically populated.)

segment.source: On the Ready tab, click Begin to start the task sequence.
segment.target: On the Ready tab, click Begin to start the task sequence.

segment.source: When the task sequence begins, it automatically initiates the in-place upgrade process by invoking the Windows setup program (Setup.exe) with the necessary command-line parameters to perform an automated upgrade, which preserves all data, settings, apps, and drivers.
segment.target: When the task sequence begins, it automatically initiates the in-place upgrade process by invoking the Windows setup program (Setup.exe) with the necessary command-line parameters to perform an automated upgrade, which preserves all data, settings, apps, and drivers.

segment.source: figure 5
segment.target: figure 5

segment.source: Figure 5.
segment.target: Figure 5.

segment.source: Upgrade from Windows 7 to Windows 10 Enterprise x64 with a task sequence.
segment.target: Upgrade from Windows 7 to Windows 10 Enterprise x64 with a task sequence.

segment.source: After the task sequence completes, the computer will be fully upgraded to Windows 10.
segment.target: After the task sequence completes, the computer will be fully upgraded to Windows 10.
